monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: The ḥabbiyye exists in this area. They used to make it in the old days. Today, they still make it, but not like before. In the past, it was made in large quantities; now, they make it in smaller amounts.
They add wheat to it—wheat. What’s it called? Chickpeas, chickpeas. Lentils, lentils. They cook it in water and add molasses and pepper, making it spicy, spicy. Then they eat it. It’s delicious.

"There is also baṣṭǝrma." —"Baṣṭǝrma?" "Yes, they make baṣṭǝrma with bulgur. They knead the bulgur, like for çig köfte, and shape it into small pieces. Then, they add minced meat (qayma) on top and place it."

Some people toast it with clarified butter, while others cook it with water. There are those who prefer it cooked in water, boiled in this way, while others like it toasted with high-quality clarified butter."

There are other dishes as well. There's 'kḅaḅḅ,' which they make with bulgur. They stuff it with meat, onions, peppers, and molasses, creating a mixture that they fill and then seal up. Some toast it in oil, while others prepare it by cooking it in water until it's ready.

There are large cooking pots here. They make a dish called 'ḥabāyib' in these pots. They cook it inside these large pots, and when it's ready, they serve it. If guests arrive, they offer them some of the dish as well.

And there is also 'gurṣa.' 'al-gurṣa ' is a type of bread here. Have you seen the bread they make and roll? 'al- gurṣa' is larger and thicker than that bread. The grandmothers put ghee and sesame on it, then fry it for breakfast in the morning. We call it 'al-gurṣa,' and they make that.
